nodes.bodyText:
By capturing the Schedulers.elastic() in an instance variable, you are using the same Scheduler with every async API. Just a heads up on not sure how this will behave.
Also, Schedulers.boundedElastic() is the preferred way now for wrapping I/O calls. Please see that too.

using the variable is fine. The elastic scheduler provided by the reactor lib is a singleton instance.
sure, I will switch to Schedulers.boundedElastic() for now (next commit). in the long run this will be replaced by Schedulers.parallel() after I fix the remaining blocking io call. (one potential blocking call is remaining).
SubsribeOn will also change the actual call - which in this case could be all the way back to azure-cosmos. Any reason why you are not using PublishOn here ?

decryption will happen when Flux/Mono emits results (after reading data from service) and so we need publishOn for decryption to ensure it runs on the desired scheduler.
encryption will happen prior to sending data to service and we have a defer operator which in conjunction of subscribeOn will ensure the actual encryption call to happen on the desired scheduler.

nodes.bodyText:
Instead of using blocking calls, since now we are going asynchronous, please try using StepVerifier from reactor-test.
Its actually built in for testing async APIs. We have used it in azure-spring-data-cosmos-test and also in azure-cosmos.
Please take a look at VeryLargeDocumentQueryTest.java and any reactive test in azure-spring-data-cosmos-test - ReactiveCosmosTemplateIT, ReactiveCourseRepositoryIT, etc.
good suggestion. Moved to StepVerifier for test validation.

Regarding these two changes (this and below) with using Flux.merge - did you do any performance testing?
Can you please share the results ?
We should make sure this doesn't break any existing cosmos APIs. Please run the full CI for this PR.

all the enrcyption code for query factored out.
This has 0 impact on perf now.
